【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Central to Zoroastrianism was the Atashkadeh, or house of fire. While it has been given many names in its time, the sentiment remains the same, and is captured adequately as rendered in the New Persian Atashkadeh.

It should be noted that Zoroastrianism outpaced the Atashkadeh by centuries: no mention of it can be found in the Avesta, Zoroastrianism's oldest text, nor is there any term that would describe such a structure in Old Persian. The Atashkadeh would not make an appearance until the late Achaemenid empire. There, it would emerge as a humble abode for votives to be made, and as a shelter for a sacred fire.

Characteristic of Atashkadeh was the gombad, a domed sanctuary where the fire would be both vouchsafed and enthroned, to burn eternal—to never be moved besides for its own good. Simple but effective, the gombad was situated in a square flanked by four arches, which a supported a dome. This allowed priests and worshipers alike easy access to the fire, and in its open design framed the surroundings so that visitors could likewise appreciate the natural elements core to Zoroastrianism. A walkway described this central structure, beyond which rooms were dedicated to congregation, rituals that didn't directly involve the fire, and the materials needed for the upkeep of the fire itself.

These typically humble Atashkadehs were however treated quite differently if home to one of the great fires of Adur Gushnasp, Adur Burzen-Mihr, or Adur Farnbag (the great fires of warriors, priests, and workers respectively). At Takht-e Soleyman, the only extant ruins confirmed to have held Adur Gushnasp have been excavated. Favoured as the great fire of warriors was by Kings of Kings, its complex was suitably impressive.

More than a mere fire temple, Takht-e Soleyman was a citadel. Two walls limned the hilltop it occupied. The inner, a thick mud-brick bulwark; the outer, which hugged the rim of the hill, stone that towered fifty feet, and studded with thirty-eight towers. Further yet, the temple itself was surrounded on three sides by a wall, with the fourth open to a lake in the crater of a volcanic rim. These fortifications were tasked with the protection of the most prized fire in all of Persia.

Pilgrims would enter through a vast courtyard, through which they'd be herded toward the lake. There, a domed room terminated in a portico that afforded pilgrims a vista of the lake in all its splendour. From there they could follow a series of pillared halls and antechambers which eventually deposited them at the grand, frieze-embellished sanctuary of the altar of Adur Gushnasp. Within this complex there were an array of rooms dedicated to everything from lesser shrines to a temple treasury. Between the crater, the elaborate plan, and its scenic surroundings, the site must have been a wonder to pilgrims seeking to pay their respects to Adur Gushnasp.
With the conquest of Islam, Atashkadeha grew scarce. Most were either destroyed or repurposed as mosques.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Poseidon was one of the twelve Olympians in ancient Greek religion and myth. He was god of the Sea and other waters; of earthquakes; and of horses. In pre-Olympian Bronze Age Greece, he was venerated as a chief deity at Pylos and Thebes. Poseidon was protector of seafarers, and of many Hellenic cities and colonies. In Homer's Iliad, Poseidon supports the Greeks against the Trojans during the Trojan War. In the Odyssey, during the sea-voyage from Troy back home to Ithaca, the Greek hero Odysseus provokes Poseidon's fury by blinding his son the Cyclops Polyphemus, resulting in Poseidon punishing him with storms, the complete loss of his ship and companions, and a ten-year delay. Poseidon is also the subject of a Homeric hymn. His Roman equivalent is Neptune.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Saturn was the Roman gold of agriculture, renewal, liberation, wealth, dissolution, and time, among other aspects. In the month of December, he was celebrated at the Saturnalia: a time for feasting, role reversals, free speech, gift-giving, and reveltry. Saturn was identified with the Greek Cronus, especially the role of Cronus in the genealogy of the Greek gods. Indeed, Jupiter was called the son of Saturn. The Temple of Saturn --the Saturnium -- in the Roman Forum contained the state treasury. It was constructed at the base of the Saturnius Mons, better known as the Capitoline Hill. It was consecrated in 497 BCE.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Minerva was the Roman goddess of wisdom and strategic warfare, and the sponsor of arts, trade, and strategy. From the second century BC onward, the Romans equated her with the Greek goddess Athena. She was the virgin goddess of music, poetry, medicine, wisdom, commerce, weaving, and the crafts. She is often depicted with her sacred creature, an owl usually named as the "owl of Minerva", which symbolised her association with wisdom and knowledge.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The cult of Serapis was introduced during the 3rd century BC on the orders of Ptolemy I Soter of Egypt as a means to unify the Greeks and Egyptians in his realm. The god was depicted as Greek in appearance, but with Egyptian trappings, and combined iconography from a great many cults, signifying both abundance and resurrection. A serapeum was any temple or religious precinct devoted to Serapis. The cultus of Serapis was spread as a matter of deliberate policy by the Ptolemaic kings, who also built an immense serapeum in Alexandria. Serapis continued to increase in popularity during the Roman period, often replacing Osiris as the consort of Isis in temples outside Egypt. In 389, a Christian mob led by the Patriarch Theophilus of Alexandria destroyed the Alexandrian serapeum, but the cult survived until all forms of pagan religion were suppressed under Theodosius I in 391.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A surau is an Islamic assembly building used for worship and religious instruction. Some of its ritual functions are similar to those of a mosque, but Surau are mostly smaller than mosques, allow men and women, and are used more for religious instruction and festive prayers. They may function as community centers, and depend more on grassroots support and funding.

【译者注：正在翻译……】[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]A priory is a monastery of men or women under religious vows that is headed by a prior or prioress. Priories may be houses of mendicant friars or nuns (such as the Dominicans, Augustinians, Franciscans, and Carmelites, for instance), or monasteries of monks or nuns (as with the Benedictines). Houses of canons regular and canonesses regular also use this term, the alternative being "canonry." In pre-Reformation England, if an abbey church was raised to cathedral status, the abbey became a Cathedral Priory. The bishop, in effect, took the place of the abbot, and the monastery itself was headed by a prior.
